speech: A zero-day vulnerability is a software flaw that is unknown to the vendor and for which no patch exists.
This means that attackers can exploit the vulnerability before the developers are even aware of it.
Zero-day exploits can be very dangerous because there is no immediate defense against them.
Attackers often discover these vulnerabilities and use them in targeted attacks.
Mitigation strategies include using intrusion detection and prevention systems, keeping software updated (as soon as patches are released), and employing behavioral analysis tools.
The term 'zero-day' refers to the fact that the vendor has had zero days to fix the flaw since its discovery by attackers.
